Lilia is a loving mother who is happy to see that her older daughter has an excellent professional career in their city since she works and contributes her monthly rent. Lilia's second son is still in high school. Her husband works as an independent contractor who buys and sells various decoration articles in the capital city.

What motivates Lilia is having no job, which would no longer allow her son to continue with his studies since before she lost her job, and her older daughter was able to obtain a professional one. For this, she started to sell some few boxes of soft drinks on a weekly basis in an excellent location of her house that is on the corner of a very busy street. Little by little, she started to have customers and her business grew in short time with her son's help.

Now she needs to invest in buying more soft drinks because her customers' overwhelming demands and thus, to be able to satisfy them. She wishes to continue her business and is seeking a total of $450, with a cancellation contract of 6 months. Let us help Lilia continue with her goals and quench her thirst for progress for her family.

Translated from Spanish by Geraldine Kim, Kiva Volunteer.

Lilia es una amorosa madre que observa con satisfacción a su hija mayor que se desempeña como una excelente profesional en su ciudad ya que trabaja y contribuye con los gastos de su hogar en forma mensual, el segundo hijo aún está en el colegio y viven en compañía de su esposo y padre que trabaja en forma independiente comprando y vendiendo diversos artículos de decoración en la capital.

A Lilia la impulsó la falta de trabajo que no le permitía continuar con los estudios de su hijo ya que antes de que perdiese el empleo logró darle una profesión a su hija mayor. Es así como empezó vendiendo unas cuantas cajas de bebidas gaseosas en forma semanal contando con la ayuda de la excelente ubicación de su casa que está en una esquina muy transitada, poco a poco empezó a tener clientela y fue creciendo su negocio en poco tiempo con la ayuda y administración de su hijo.

Ahora necesita invertir en la compra de más bebidas gaseosas debido a la desbordante demanda de sus clientes y para poder llevar adelante su objetivo esta solicitando la suma de 450 dólares, con un pacto de cancelación de seis meses. Ayudemos a continuar con las metas de Lilia está en nosotros poder ayudarla para que siga saciando la sed de progreso de su familia

loans.use: Buy supplies of beverage to meet sales demands

loans.name: Dam

texts.en: Mrs. Dam S. M., aged 31, sells beans in the market to earn $3 per day in revenue.  Her husband, aged 44, works as a broker, buying and selling potatoes to earn about $4 per day.  They have five children, two who work digging up potatotes to earn $3 per day collectively, and three who are students.  Mrs. Dam is requesting this loan of $800 to purchase a large crop of potatoes from a farmer and resell them in the market at a higher profit margin than she earns on beans.  She plans to use the additional income from this transaction to pay her children’s school fees and save for future business investments.

loans.use: To purchase potatoes to resell in the market.

payments.comment: Congratulation! Your Kiva loan has been repaid early. Thank you for interest helping Cambodian entrepreneurs like Dam Srey Mut and sustain their business. Your loan has made them different. We do hope that you will continue support the poor entrepreneurs in Cambodia through CREDIT MFI in the future. Best Regard, Vichet Ouch, Kiva Coordinator at CREDIT MFI, Phnom Penh Office.

loans.name: Bin

texts.en: Mrs. Bin S., aged 36, works with her husband to farm their plot of land.  They earn about $5 per day in revenue from the sale of their vegetables in the market.  They have four children who are students.  In order to diversify their income and account for seasonal changes in farming, Mrs. Bin is requesting this loan of $500 to purchase a horse and cart for her husband to operate a transportation business.  When he has time to leave the farm, he plans to operate a taxi service for his rural community and increase the family’s income, allowing them to better educate their children and support their family.

loans.use: To purchase a horse and cart to operate a transportation service.

loans.name: Chea

texts.en: Mrs. Chea K., aged 28, sells bananas in the market to earn $5 per day in revenue.  Her husband is a laborer who makes $1 each day.  They have one young child as well as Mrs. Chea’s brother who lives with them and depends on her income.  She is requesting a loan of $200 to help her brother start a transportation business and contribute to the family income. With this loan, she can purchase a horse and cart so that he can transport passengers among the villages and earn $2-4 per day.  This will greatly increase her family’s standard of living and provide the resources to educate her child.

loans.use: To purchase a horse and cart to start a transportation business.

payments.comment:
Congratulations! Chea Kunthy has fully repaid this Kiva loan early.

Thank you for your support of Cambodian entrepreneurs. Lenders like you allow entrepreneurs around the world access to low-interest loans to finance their small businesses and support their families.

We hope you will continue your support by reinvesting in another Kiva entrepreneur.

Sincerely,
Isadora Tang, Kiva Fellow, Cambodia

loans.name: Nuon

texts.en: Mrs. Nuon C., aged 31, makes and sells desserts out of her house to earn about $3.30 per day in income.  Her husband is a laborer, earning about $2.30 per day.  They have two children who are currently too young to attend school.  She is requesting a loan of $800 to purchase a plot of land to grow vegetables to feed her family.  She plans to use any remaining funds to purchase dessert supplies so that she can vary the types of sweets she makes in response to client demand.

loans.use: To purchase land to grow vegetables and purchase dessert making ingredients.

payments.comment:
Congratulations! Nuon Chrip has repaid this Kiva loan early!

Thanks to lenders like you, entrepreneurs around the world have access to low-interest loans to help them support their small businesses and families. We hope that you will continue investing in Kiva entrepreneurs.

Sincerely,
Isadora Tang, Kiva Fellow, Cambodia

loans.name: Sok

texts.en: Mrs. Sok R., aged 50, sells traditional Cambodian medicine to earn about $12 per day in revenue.  Profits vaR. according to the type of medicines her clients request.  Her husband grows vegetables to feed the family.  They have one child who is a high school student.  Mrs. Sok is requesting this loan of $1200 in order to increase her inventoR. of medicines to meet growing client demands.  Part of the loan will also be used to purchase an electric water pump to irrigate the family’s farm and increase crop yield.

loans.use: To increase inventory of traditional medicines and purchase a water pump for farm irrigation.

payments.comment:
Congratulations! Sok Ry has fully repaid this Kiva loan early.

Thank you for your support of Cambodian entrepreneurs. Lenders like you allow entrepreneurs around the world access to low-interest loans to finance their small businesses and support their families.

We hope you will continue your support by reinvesting in another Kiva entrepreneur.

Sincerely,
Isadora Tang, Kiva Fellow, Cambodia

loans.name: Sambat

texts.en: Mrs. Sambat S., aged 51, sells a variety of grocery products and earns about $1 per day in income.  She and her husband have five children - one who is a laborer, one who is a motor-taxi driver, and three who are students.  Mrs. Sambat S. is requesting this loan in order to purchase a motorbike so that her husband can become a motor-taxi driver and earn about $2 per day to supplement the family income.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to start a motor-taxi business.

loans.name: Eang

texts.en: Mrs. Eang S., aged 45, sells grocery products at a stand near her home to earn about $2 per day.  Her husband is a mechanic who earns about $3 per day.  They have four children, one who helps his father and three who are students.  Mrs. Eang S. is requesting this loan in order to purchase spare vehicle parts to expand the range of her husband’s inventory to grow his mechanic business.  She plans to use the resulting increase in income to invest in additional grocery products to grow her business to meet customers' demands and support her children’s education.

loans.use: To purchase vehicle parts to expand a mechanic business.

loans.name: Sek

texts.en: Mrs. Sek C., aged 40, sells duck eggs at the open air market to make about $6 per day in revenue.  Her husband is a motor-taxi driver, earning about $2.50 per day.  They have three children who are students.  Mrs. Sek is requesting a loan of $1200 to build a home with walls.  They are pictured in their current home, which is inadequate to protect the family from storms.

loans.use: To build a home with walls.

payments.comment:
Congratulations! Sek Chanthoeun has paid back this Kiva loan early.

Thanks to your support, entrepreneurs around the world have access to low-interest loans to invest into their small businesses and families. We hope that you will continue your support  and reinvest your loan into another entrepreneur.

Sincerely,
Isadora Tang, Kiva Fellow, Cambodia

loans.name: Leng

texts.en: Mrs. Leng S., aged 52, works as a broker buying and selling yams.  She earns about $1 per day.  Her husband works as the village chief and as a motor-taxi driver, earning about $2 per day.  They have six children.  Four children are students, one child helps his father at work, and one child is a laborer.  In order to buy yams in bulk at a lower purchase cost, she is requesting a loan of $800.  Her husband is pictured in the photo as she was not available at the time.

loans.use: To purchase yams for resale.

payments.comment:
Congratulations! Leng Seam has fully repaid this Kiva loan early.

Thank you for your support of Cambodian entrepreneurs. Lenders like you allow entrepreneurs around the world access to low-interest loans to finance their small businesses and support their families.

We hope you will continue your support by reinvesting in another Kiva entrepreneur.

Sincerely,
Isadora Tang, Kiva Fellow, Cambodia

loans.name: Prum

texts.en: Mrs. Prum T., aged 36, works selling vegetables and earns about $1 of profit per day.  Her husband is a farmer and grows vegetables to sell, earning about $1.60 per day.  They have five children. One child works at a private company, earning about $2 per day, and the other four children are students.  For the past few years, the family has rented the plot of farmland they grow their vegetables on.  Mrs. Prum T. is requesting a loan of $500 in order to purchase a plot of farmland of their own along with additional seeds to grow their own crops to sell in the market.

loans.use: To purchase land and seeds to farm.

payments.comment: Congratulation! Your Kiva loan has been repaid early. Thank you for interest helping Cambodian entrepreneurs like Prum Tun and sustain their business. Your loan has made them different. We do hope that you will continue support the poor entrepreneurs in Cambodia through CREDIT MFI in the future. Best Regard, Vichet Ouch, Kiva Coordinator at CREDIT MFI, Phnom Penh Office.

loans.name: Ababil

texts.en: Ababil is an Internally Displaced Person from Fizuli region located in southeast part of Azerbaijan. She and her family were relocated to Lokbatan settlement of Baku city as a result of Armenian-Azerbaijan military conflict over Garabakh. She rents a booth in the local market and trades canned vegetables, dry fruits and spices. She has been in this business for more than 10 years. She wants to increase the volume of sales, invest more in her business and increase her income. She has had two previous loans from Normicro Baku branch. Now she applies again for $1200 to invest in business.

loans.use: To increase working capital and increase amount for sale

loans.name: Chea

texts.en: Mrs. Chea Y., aged 41, sells clothes in a market in the nearby town. She earns around $2.40 per day in profit.  Her husband is a farmer who makes about $1.60 per day by selling his vegetables.  They have six children, five who are students and one who works in a garment factory making about $2.30 per day.  She is requesting a loan of $500 in order to purchase more fashionable clothes to meet her customers’ demands and use the remaining funds to repair the family home.

loans.use: To purchase more fashionable clothing to sell for profit to repair her house.

loans.name: Choy

texts.en: Mrs. Choy K. A., aged 34, works producing mortar for use in construction.  She earns around $2 per day.  Her husband is an electrician, making about $3 per day.  They do not have children.  She is requesting a loan of $800 in order to purchase more stones to pound into mortar.  By increasing her inventory, she can fulfill her customers' larger orders and increase her profit margin.  Her husband is pictured in the photo as she was not available at the time.

loans.use: To purchase stones to pound into mortar for use in construction.

loans.name: Azad

texts.en: Azad was born in Baku. He is 23 years old and is not married yet. He runs a furniture workshop where he repairs furniture and makes new furniture as well. He has been in this business for three years, but his business is not well developed yet. He wants to repair the workshop, to buy necessary tools and equipment for work, and and to develop his business. He applied to Normicro Baku branch for a loan in amount of $1000 for the first time as he has little of his own funds to invest in his business. He wants to buy tools first.

loans.use: To buy tools and equipment

payments.comment: Correction due to underpayment for business 22013

loans.name: Limka

texts.en: Limka is an Internally Displaced Person from Fizuli region located in south-east part of Azerbaijan. She and her family were relocated to Lokbatan settlement of Baku city as a result of Armenian-Azerbaijan military conflict over Garabakh. She rents a booth in the local market and trades pickled vegetables and dairy products. She has been in this business for more than 10 years. She wants to increase the volume of sales, invest more in her business and increase her income. She has had two previous loans from Normicro Baku branch. Now she applies again for $1000 to invest in business.

loans.use: To increase working capital and to increase products for sale

payments.comment: Correction due to underpayment for business 22014

loans.name: Ramila

texts.en: Ramila is an Internally Displaced Person from the Fizuli region located in southeast part of Azerbaijan. She and her family were relocated to Lokbatan settlement of the city of Baku as a result of Armenian-Azerbaijan military conflict over Garabakh. She rents a booth in the local market and trades (sells) various household items. She has sold in the local market for more than 10 years. She wants to increase the volume of sales, invest more in her business and increase her income. She is applying for $1000 to invest in business.

loans.use: To increase working capital and increase items for sale

payments.comment: Correction due to overpayment for business 22015

loans.name: Rovshan

texts.en: Rovshan was born in the city of Baku. He is 30 years old, married, and has two children. He rents a shop in Lokbatan settlement and trades (sells) food stuff. His business is new; only a year ago he started this business. He invested a lot into his business in the beginning. Now he has few of his own funds to keep up the variety and assortment of goods. He applied to Normicro Baku branch for a loan in amount of 900 AZN (about $1075 USD) to invest in his business and increase his working capital.

loans.use: To increase working capital to improve the variety of goods sold

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Norwegian Microcredit LLC (Normicro) - Oct 24, 2008)
Correction due to underpayment for business 22016

loans.name: Khut

texts.en: Mrs. Khut H., aged 35, works as a broker buying and selling yams.  She earns about $2 per day.  Her husband works as a motor-taxi driver, earning about $2 per day.  They have five children who are all students.  In order to buy yams in bulk for a lower purchase cost, she would like to request a loan of $800.  This will increase her margins and revenue, allowing her to save the additional income to pay for her children’s education.  Her husband is pictured in the photo as she was not available at the time.

loans.use: To purchase yams in bulk for resale.

loans.name: San

texts.en: Mr. San T., aged 38, works growing and selling mushrooms at his home.  He makes about $12 per day in revenue.  His wife runs a stand at the market selling fish, making about $2 per day in profit.  They have five children, two of whom assist him in growing mushrooms, and three who are students.  Mr. San T. would like to request a loan of $1000 in order to purchase additional seedlings to expand his inventory of mushrooms to meet customer demand.  This will lead to increased income to support his family and pay for his children’s education.

loans.use: To purchase mushroom seedlings to expand his business.

loans.name: Pav

texts.en: Mr. Pav L., age 25, is single and lives with his older sister. He makes and sells traditional Cambodia noodles that he sells in the market. He can earn an average of $2.50 per day which he contributes towards the family’s household expenses. He would like to create a fish breeding business and would like to finance his startup with a loan of $800 to invest in a water pump, pipes, and fish food. This new business will increase the family’s income and raise their standard of living.

loans.use: To start a fish breeding business.

loans.name: Sek

texts.en: Mrs. Sek M., age 54, works with her husband to farm rice crops and vegetables, collectively earning about $2 per day. They have three children who together run a tailoring business out of their home. She would like to request a loan of $700 in order to purchase additional sewing machines, thread, and cloth to increase the business’ output capacity in order to serve growing customer demands. This will expand the tailoring shop, leading to increased income  and raising the family’s standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine, needles, thread, and cloth.

payments.comment:
Congratulation to Mrs. Sek Mey!!!!!!!!

Now She is able to pay off her loan very early. On behalf of Mrs Sek Mey, I would like to say greatly thank to all the lenders who always support and help to our poor entrepreneurs. your loan can make different. 

we will provide the Journal update of Sek Mey family as soon as we could so that you will understand what different your loan make on her and her family. 

Many Thanks again

loans.name: Sok

texts.en: Mrs. Sok S., age 39, works with her father buying and reselling recyclable items, earning together around $5 per day. She has four children, one who is a garment worker earning around $2.30 per day, one who is a welder earning around $2 per day, and two who are students. She would like to request a loan of $500 to purchase more recyclable items in bulk, lowering the purchase cost and increasing her margins on the resale price. She plans to use the additional income generated from her business expansion to reinvest in her inventory and save funds for her children’s education.

loans.use: To purchase recyclable materials to resell.

loans.name: Suy

texts.en: Mr. Suy C. E., age 34, works as a carpenter producing beds, tables, cupboards, wardrobes, and other furniture. His wife sells the products her husband makes, earning the family about $4 per day in profit. ThE. have four children, one who works in a garment factory earning $2 per day, one who is a welder making $2 per day, and two who are students. He would like to request a loan of $400 in order to purchase more wood to supply their carpentry business. Purchasing in bulk will save costs, and increasing the stock of wood will allow him to fulfill larger orders for the customers. This will increase both margins and revenue. He plans to use the additional income to reinvest in the growth of their business and support their children’s education. His wife is pictured in the photograph.

loans.use: To purchase wood for a carpentry shop.

loans.name: Yem

texts.en: Mrs. Yem K. N., age 37, is a street-vendor selling dried fish, earning around $2 per day in profit. Her husband sells vegetables to earn around $3 per day. They have one child who is a student. She would like to request a loan of $500 in order to purchase a motorbike to transport their vegetables and fish from the market to their stalls. This will increase efficiency, allowing them to purchase the freshest produce and open their stall earlier in the morning, thereby increasing access to customers and increasing revenue.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to transport food goods for sale.

loans.name: Ma

texts.en: Mrs. Ma C., age 37, sells various sculptures that her husband makes, earning about $3 per day in profit. Her husband makes about $4 per day by selling the sculptures to a wholesaler, as well as through his wife's sales. They have four children, two of whom are students and two of whom have moved away from home. She would like to request a loan of $500 in order to purchase additional raw materials for her husband to use in making sculptures. Purchasing in bulk will lower costs and increasing the inventory of sculptures they sell will raise revenue. They plan to use the increased income to reinvest in the growth of their business and pay for their children’s education.

loans.use: To purchase materials to make sculptures.

loans.name: Bol

texts.en: Mrs. Bol S. R., age 55, works grinding beans by hand and selling the shelled beans to members of her community, earning about $10 per day in revenue. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver who earns around $4 per day. They have seven children, three who work in a garment factory earning around $2 per day each, one who is a motor-taxi driver, and three who are students. She would like to request a loan of $1,200 in order to purchase a grinding mill to more quickly grind the shells off the beans and increase her output of product to meet customer demand. This will increase her income and help her fund her children’s education and increase the standard of living for her family.

loans.use: To purchase a grinding mill to shell beans.

loans.name: Srim

texts.en: Mrs. Srim Y., age 44, produces and sells traditional medicinal rice wine, earning around $3 per day. Her husband, age 45, works grinding the husk off rice, earning around $3 per day as well. They have three children, one who is a student and two who work in a garment factory earning about $2 per day. She would like to request a loan of $900 in order to purchase more rice stock to increase her production of wine. She would also like to use part of the loan to rent an adjacent plot of farmland for her family to grow their own crops to eat.

loans.use: To purchase additional rice to make medicinal wine.

loans.name: Prum

texts.en: Mrs. Prum N., age 44, works with her husband collecting and buying recyclable items that they resell to a recycling plant, making together about $7 per day in revenue. They have two children who are students. She would like to request a loan of $1000 to purchase a motorbike to use for business transportation to more quickly collect product and transport it to the recycling plant. This will greatly improve the efficiency of their business, allowing them to sell more product and increase income for the family.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to expand her recycling business.

loans.name: Prum

texts.en: Mrs. Prum N., age 44, works with her husband collecting and buying recyclable items that they resell to a recycling plant, making together about $7 per day in revenue. They have two children who are students. She would like to request a loan of $1000 to purchase a motorbike to use for business transportation to more quickly collect product and transport it to the recycling plant. This will greatly improve the efficiency of their business, allowing them to sell more product and increase income for the family.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to expand her recycling business.

loans.name: Men

texts.en: Mrs. Men S., age 49, is a housewife with two children who are carpenters. Her husband is a construction foreman, earning about $4 per day. She would like to request a loan of $500 to purchase additional wood and supplies for her children’s carpentry business. By increasing the stock of raw materials, her children can increase output to meet growing customer demand as well as take advantage of bulk discounts on purchasing costs. Her husband is pictured in the photo.

loans.use: To purchase carpentry materials.

loans.name: Sim

texts.en: Mrs. Sim R., age 57, works buying and reselling recyclable items, earning about $10 per day in revenue. They have three children who are married with their own families. She would like to request a loan of $600 in order to purchase a motorbike for her husband to operate a motor-taxi business and earn about $3 per day in profit. This will double the family’s current income and allow Mrs. Sim R. to invest in growing her own business.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to operate a motor-taxi business.

loans.name: Man

texts.en: Mrs. Man K., age 61, is a housewife. Her husband sells traditional medicine, earning about $10 per day in revenue. They have two children who help their father to sell medicine. She would like to request a loan of $1,000 in order to purchase a motorbike to use for her family’s transportation. Her husband is pictured in the photo.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for the family's transportation.

loans.name: Sam

texts.en: Mrs. Sam P., age 52, works collecting and reselling recyclable items, making around $6 per day in revenue. They have four children, one who is a student and three who assist their mother in her recycling business. She would like to request a loan of $500 in order to purchase a motorbike so that her husband can work as a motor-taxi driver to earn about $3 per day in profit. This will greatly increase the family’s income, allowing her to invest in the growth of her business and increasing the family’s standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to start a motor-taxi business.

payments.comment:
Congratulations! Your loan to Sam Phal has been paid back early. 

Your support of entrepreneurs like Sam Phal greatly help to contribute to the success of their small businesses. We hope you will continue lending to entrepreneurs through Kiva and CREDIT.

Best regards, 
Isadora Tang,
Kiva Fellow
Cambodia

loans.name: Tuy

texts.en: Mrs. Tuy S., age 47, is a widow who sells rice at a busy market, making about $10 per day in revenue. Her two children are bakers, making bread at a nearby bakery store. She would like to request a loan of $1,000 to purchase rice in bulk, which will lower her cost per kilo of rice and increase her inventory to meet customer demand. The greater margins will increase her income, which will raise the standard of living for her family and provide savings in case of an emergency.

loans.use: To purchase rice in bulk for resale.

loans.name: Juana Bonifacio

texts.en:
Juana, 53 years old, is a very successful and hard-working woman who believes in the value of persistence. Last year she started her business, a small grocery store where she sells basic foodstuffs to the people. Juana’s husband is a taxi driver and works in Santo Domingo, the capital. The couple has 6 grown up children.

Bi-weekly, Juana goes to the capital to purchase products to supply her business. Currently, she is short of some goods such as oats, chocolate, milk, rice and flour. She is requesting a loan to purchase those products so that she can ‘correctly’ satisfy her clientele’s needs.

loans.use: To spend in the acquisition of goods such as chocolate, milk, rice and flour to supply her grocery store. That way, the entrepreneur will be able to satisfy her customers' needs.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Make improvements to his home and purchase more goods for resale

loans.name: Cleris

texts.en:
Cleris Diana has 3 years of experience with her business. She and her husband decided to get into the office supply business after owning a small food business run out of their home. They work every day of the week from 7:00 AM until 8:00 PM.

The first loan Cleris had with Mifex and Kiva was used to invest in school supplies, gift wrapping, and beauty supplies for hair. Due to the high demand for office supplies, her business was competitive and her overall income increased. Glerys and her husband are very dedicated to their business and their customers appreciate the service and attention they provide.

Cleris Diana is 41 years old and is married. She has 3 children, 2 of whom are still in school. Her husband, apart from helping with the shop, works doing maintenance for a hotel in the city. In order to continue to provide excellent service to her clients Glerys wants to use her second loan to purchase more merchandise. She hopes that with the increase in income, she can run a stable business and continue to provide for her family.

See her first Kiva loan here: http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&action=about&id=7333

loans.use: Invest in more merchandise

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Invest in many different types of merchandise

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Fix up her store and buy more merchandise

loans.name: Eang

texts.en: Mrs. Eang S. V., age 47, is a vendor in the market earning around $2 per day. Her husband is a taxi driver, earning about $5 per day. They have two children, one who is a student and one who is married and living outside the home. She would like to request a loan of $1000 in order to help her husband replace his old taxi which is too broken-down to continue to operate. They predict that having a more reliable car will allow him to travel further distances for clients, increasing fares and subsequently increase the family’s income. They plan to use the addional income to reinvest in the growth of their businesses, finance their child’s education, and raise their family’s standard of living.

loans.use: To replace a broken-down taxi

loans.name: Sum

texts.en: Mrs. Sum T., age 37, works on a farm growing crops, earning around $2 each day from selling the crops to a wholesaler. Her husband, age 38, works as a horse-cart driver, transporting passengers in his community to earn around $3.50 each day. She would like to request this loan to purchase another horse to expand their transportation business and also purchase additional seeds for farming.

loans.use: To purchase an additional horse and seeds

payments.comment:
Congratulations! Sum Thart has fully repaid this Kiva loan early.

Thank you for your support of Cambodian entrepreneurs. Lenders like you allow entrepreneurs around the world access to low-interest loans to finance their small businesses and support their families.

We hope you will continue your support by reinvesting in another Kiva entrepreneur.

Sincerely,
Isadora Tang, Kiva Fellow, Cambodia

loans.name: Touch

texts.en: Mrs. Touch T., age 28, sells grocery products from her home to the people in her community, earning around $16.00 in revenue. Her grocery business sells bulk items like sacks of rice which increase her revenue but not necessarily her profits. Her husband works at a carpentry shop, earning about $3 per day in income. The do not have children, but her dependent mother lives with them. In order to expand the variety of the products she sells so as to better meet her customers’ demands, she would like to request a loan of $700 to expand her inventory.

loans.use: To purchase additional grocery inventory

loans.name: Chheang

texts.en: Mrs. Chheang H., age 36, runs a small stand at her home selling grocery products, earning about $2 per day. Her husband works as a driver for a company earning about $3 per day. They have three children, two who are students and one infant. She would like to request a loan of $600 in order to purchase a greater variety of products to meet her customers’ demands. Increasing her inventory will allow her to diversify her business and increase revenue. She plans to use the resulting additional income to help fund her children’s education and reinvest in her business.

loans.use: To purchase a greater variety of inventory for her grocery store

payments.comment:
Congratulations! Chheang Hong has repaid the Kiva loan early via CREDIT MFI. Thank you for your support of Cambodian entrepreneurs. We hope you will continue this support in the future.

Best regards,
Isadora Tang
Kiva Fellow
Cambodia

loans.name: Fazalraman

texts.en: Fazalraman lives in district 4 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is educated and married with 4 children: two sons and two daughters. He has a retail shop. He has a lot of experience in his job. He wants to expand his business, so he has requested an individual loan to buy extra materials like boxes of chocolates and bags of sweets. He wants to improve his income and help his family more. He is happy, and he would like to thank AFSG for this loan.

loans.use: To buy extra materials like boxes of chocolates and bags of sweets

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles is a professional tailor aged 38 with four children: two boys and two girls aged twelve, eight, five, and one respectively. Working in a predominantly female industry, Charles makes suits for men and women and clothing of African design. He has been in the business for the last decade. His professional touch has greatly boosted his business.

He also makes uniforms for pupils of two primary schools. Charles has come up with an idea of penetrating the lakeshore market where demand for uniforms is quite high because there are no professional designers on the lakeshore. He is optimistic that this will create more business for him, and therefore more income. Despite being a professional tailor, he works in a poor environment (slum) due to lack of adequate funds to rent a place in a better working environment.

He would like to borrow $300 to buy raw materials to boost his business in the coming festive season. He would be in position to repay the loan in six months.

loans.use: Purchase of a bale of clothes

loans.name: Alberto Ribeiro

texts.pt:
Alberto Ribeiro M. is married and has 5 children. He lives in Maputo, Mozambique and owns an upholstery shop where he upholsters buses and vans' seats, as well as chairs and sofas. Having paid his first loan in full, he is requesting a second one, which he will use to buy fabric, padding and other materials for his business.

Translated from Portuguese by Aline Pereira, Kiva Volunteer.

Alberto Ribeiro M. é casado e pai de 5 filhos.Vive no bairro 3 de Fevereiro em Maputo.Tem uma Estufaria e uma barraca na mesma zona. Faz cadeiras para meios de transporte semi-colectivo e mobília de sala de visita.Está no 2º ciclo, no primeiro ciclo tomou 6.000MT e pagou em 6 meses sem problemas. No 2º ciclo vai tomar 9.000MT também pagáveis em 6 meses.

loans.use: To buy fabric, padding and other materials for his upholstery business

loans.name: Margarida Mário

texts.pt:
Margarida Mário T., 33, is a widow and mother of three young children. She lives in Maputo, Mozambique where she sells groceries, cleaning products, etc at a street stand. She joined the credit program in March and is now in her second cycle of loans. She will use the money to increase her inventory and plans to apply part of the profits to the construction of a house for her family.

Translated from Portuguese by Aline Pereira, Kiva Volunteer.

Margarida Mário T. tem 33 anos de idade, é viúva e mãe de 3 filhos. Vive no bairro 3 de Fevereiro em Maputo. Tem uma barraca na qual vende diversos produtos alimentares como arroz, açúcar bolachas farinha de milho, sardinhas, leite condensado, produtos de limpeza, etc. Entrou para o programa em Março de 2007 e tomou como 1º empréstimo 6.000MT. Vai ao 2º ciclo e vai tomar 5.000MT em 5 meses.O valor dos empréstimo é investido no negócio e na construção de habitação própria.

loans.use: Stock increase

loans.name: José Salvador

texts.pt:
José Salvador S., single, father of a young child, has a stand in the Xipmanine market in Maputo, Mozambique where he sells cosmectics and beauty supplies. José has paid previous loans timely and in full, and has seen considerable improvement to his business since he joined the program, in 2005. He plans to use his 5th cycle loan to buy more supplies for his business.

Translated from Portuguese by Aline Pereira, Kiva Volunteer.

José Salvador S. tem23 anos de idade, é solteiro e pai de um filho. Tem uma banca no mercado Xipamanine e vende diversos produtos de beleza(cosméticos). Entrou para o programa em Setembro de 2005 com um empréstimo inicial de 8.000MT. Vai para o 5º ciclo e pretende um empréstimo de 20.000MT para pagarem em 6 meses. O cliente tem se comportado muito bem no reembolso dos empréstimos e teve um crescimento do negócio considerável.

loans.use: Stock increase

loans.name: Rosa Maria  Marques

texts.pt:
Rosa Maria Marques V. L. is married and has three children. A teacher, Rosa is also engaged in the business of selling grocery staples from her home in Matola, Mozambique. New to the credit program, she will use her first loan to increase her business inventory.

Translated from Portuguese by Aline Pereira, Kiva Volunteer.

Rosa Maria Marques V. L. é casada e mãe de três filhos.É professora e tem uma barraca na sua residência onde vende produtos de 1ª necessidade. É nova no programa e vai tomar 6.000MT para pagar em 5 meses.

loans.use: Stock increase

loans.name: Anabela Ernesto

texts.pt:
Anabella Ernesto C. lives with her partner and young son in Maputo, Mozambique. She joined the credit program to invest on her business of selling peeled chestnut at the central farmers market. She will use her loan to stock up on chestnuts, so that her business is not affected by the lows in chestnut production, which occur from time to time.

Translated from Portuguese by Aline Pereira, Kiva Volunteer.

Anabela Ernesto C. vive maritalmente e é mãe de um filho. Entrou para o programa como cliente grupal com um empréstimo de 1.800MT. O negócio da cliente é o da Compra, descasque e Venda da amêndoa da castanha de cajú.Vende a castanha no mercado central em Maputo. Consegue comprar mais de dez sacos de castanha e armazena para fazer face à procura nos momentos em que há falta.

loans.use: To buy enough chestnut so as not to be affected by the lows in chestnut production that occur from time to time.

loans.name: Keo

texts.en:
Mrs. Keo S., age 58, sells vegetables in the market to earn about $3 per day. Her husband works as a driver in a private company, earning about $3 per day. They have six children, four who work at a food manufacturing company earning $120 collectively, one who is a mechanic, and one who is a student.

Mrs. S. would like to request a second loan from Kiva borrowers. In August 2007 she took out a loan of $200 to buy tools so that her son could become a mechanic. She has had no trouble making her payments on the first loan. She would now like to borrow an additional $200 to expand her own business by purchasing fruits and grocery products for her inventory to turn her vegetable stand into a grocery stall. The remainder of the loan will be used to finance a motorbike to use for business transportation. She will be able to more quickly pick up and transport her vegetables more to the marketplace, allowing her to arrive earlier with fresher produce to meet customer demand.

In the future, she would like to save enough money to expand her business by adding additional grocery products, vegetables, and butchery items to fulfill customer demand.

loans.use: To purchase fruits and grocery products to turn her vegetable stall into a grocery store

loans.name: Churi Maiya

texts.en:
Mrs. Churi Maiya S., 48 years old, lives in Gorkho, Lalitpur, Nepal. Most people in this town are busy in small businesses. Her husband is also 48 years old. He is a driver. In her family she has three members. She opened her grocery shop 4 months ago. Her son also works in the same shop.

Mrs. S. seeks US$ 175 as a loan to buy ice cream for her shop. In summer the demand for ice cream is very high. With her profits she plans to invest further in her grocery shop.

loans.use: To buy ice cream for re-sale in her little grocery store

loans.name: Eam

texts.en: Mrs. Eam N., age 28, is a widow with one child in school. She works at the market, selling various kinds of tires, earning about $4 in revenue per day. She has had one previous Kiva loan for $350 in July 2007 in order to purchase additional inventory. Her sales are strong, she was able to repay the first loan on time each month, and would like to purchase additional tires to meet her growing customer demands. She would like to request a second loan of $350 in order to purchase additional inventory and expand her business.

loans.use: To expand her inventory of tires to sell

loans.name: Pouy

texts.en: Mrs. Pouy S., age 41, makes baskets and sells them to a wholesale dealer, earning $3 per day. Her husband is a construction foreman earning $4 per day. They have five children, four who are students and one who is too young for school. In order to meet growing consumer demand, she would like to borrow $200 in order to purchase more bamboo, reeds, and other materials needed to create her baskets. This will increase her output and therefore increase her income. She plans to use the increased income to reinvest in her business and finance her children’s education.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to weave baskets

loans.name: Min

texts.en: Mrs. Min Y., age 58, works with her husband on their farmland to grow rice crops and vegetables, earning about $2 per day together. They have five children, three who work and two who are students. She would like to request a loan of $1000 in order to purchase a cow to help them plow their field. Using a cow to carry heavy loads and pull the plow will increase their efficiency, allowing them to plant crops more densely and lighten the physical burden. She is pictured with her daughter in the photo.

loans.use: To purchase a cow to plow the fields

loans.name: Jamshed

texts.en:
Jamshed is one of the active clients of MicroInvest. He has a little shop of food products. He became a client of MicroInvest in 2005 and spent his first loan to purchase the first batch of candies and other food products. The business was successful, and Jamshed decided to conclude an agreement with one distribution firm for a long partnership.

Today his shop is one of the known shops in the food market. He is a very cheerful person, and he is always glad to meet everyone who comes to his shop. All his clients are satisfied with his service. Jamshed tries to make his assortment of food products more competitive. In the near future he dreams of opening a cafe for his clients. Presently he is requesting $600 to purchase 4 boxes of chocolates, 2 boxes of fruit drops, and several kind of biscuits and cakes.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Yous

texts.en: Mrs. Yous H., age 50, works with her husband on a plot of farmland growing rice, together earning around $3 each day. They have seven children, three who are employed, one of whom works as a tailor, and three who are students. She would like to request a loan of $1000 in order to purchase a sewing machine for her daughter to better operate her business. A sewing machine will mechanize her operations and allow her to produce much more to meet customer demand and raise revenue.

loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Mrs. Sok S., age 56, works with her husband in their rice paddy growing rice and vegetables, earning around $3 per day in income together. They have eight children, two who are employed in an undisclosed job, two who are married, three who are students, and one who would like to be a hairdresser.

Mrs. Sok S. would like to request a loan of $1200 in order to purchase the supplies needed to open a hair salon. This would allow her daughter to be self-sufficient and also bring additional income into the family to support her siblings’ education. Mrs. Sok S. is pictured with her daughter in the photo.

loans.use: To purchase supplies and equiptment needed to open a hair salon

loans.name: Gayatri

texts.en:
Mrs. Gayatri D., 35 years old, resident of Kulashwor, Nepal, lives in a single (i.e., not extended) family with her husband Shyam D. and two sons whose ages are 3 and 1 respectively. Her older son is in pre-primary school.

Mr. and Mrs. D. opened a grocery shop a few years ago. They both work in their own shop, but due to the lack of business capital they can't expand their business. So in order to expand their business, Mrs. D. is requesting a loan of US$ 175. With this amount she will buy noodles, biscuits, rice, etc. for her shop. She is ready to pay back the loan on a monthly basis.

loans.use: To buy grocery goods to stock her shop

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Patan Business and Professional Women - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Ros

texts.en: Mrs Ros L., age 54, works renting rooms to the people in her area, making about $3 per day in profit. Her husband is a government commune officer, making less than $1 per day. They have two children, one who is a garment worker and one who is a student. She would like to borrow $600 to help her purchase a car for her family’s transportation.

loans.use: To purchase a car for the family's transportation

loans.name: Yam

texts.en:
Mrs. Yam S., 22 years old, is a tailor in the town of Kulashwor in Kathmandu, Nepal. Her husband's name is Dinesh S. and he is working outside the country.

Mrs. S. opened her tailoring shop 4 years ago. She makes school uniforms for both boys and girls. She prefers to make popular dresses like Kurta Sulwar, blouses, ladies' long dresses, Makhshi, and other such clothes. Before starting her own business, Mrs. S. took a 6-month training course in tailoring. Now she need US$ 175 as a loan to buy raw materials like cotton cloth for her tailoring work.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for her tailoring business

loans.name: Maiya

texts.en:
Mrs. Maiya P., 24 years old, lives in Bholdhoka, Lalitpur, Nepal. Bholdhoka is situated in Kathmandu valley and most of the people in this region are engaged in business activities.

Mrs. P. has one son, two years old. Her husband Shankar P. works for the police department. Mrs. P. opened a grocery shop 4 years ago. She needs US$175 as a loan to buy noodles, rice, biscuits, and so on for her shop. Her income is to be used for the better education for her children and she also wants to support her family in financial matters.

loans.use: To buy grocery goods to stock her shop

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Patan Business and Professional Women - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Khiev

texts.en: Mrs. Khiev Y., age 50, works with her husband selling vegetables at a open-air market, earning about $5 per day collectively. They have nine children. Three children are married, four are students, one is employed in an undisclosed job, and one son would like to become a tuk-tuk (three-wheeled taxi) driver. She would like to request a loan of $1000 to purchase a tuk-tuk cart to fit over the back of her son’s motor-bike so that he can earn up to $5 per day as a tuk-tuk driver.

loans.use: To purchase a tuk-tuk (motorcycle-cart) to become a tuk-tuk taxi driver

loans.name: Mankumari

texts.en:
Mrs. Mankumari R. M. lives in Bholdhoka, Lalitpur, Nepal. She lives in a single (i.e., not extended) family with her husband Kumar R. M. and one son. Her husband works in a steel shop. Her son is attending primary school. Mrs. M. opened a grocery shop two years ago to raise the living standard of her family. Their financial condition is not good so they can't provide better education for their son because in Nepal the cost of education is very high. To overcome this problem she opened a grocery shop.

Due to lack of capital, she can’t fully stock her shop. So she is asking for her first loan in the amount of US$ 175 to buy goods like rice, lentils, noodles, etc. She plans to spend her income to provide better education for her son and wishes to help her husband to upgrade the quality of life of her family.

loans.use: To buy gocery goods for re-sale

loans.name: Mankumari

texts.en:
Mrs. Mankumari K., 44 years old, is a tailor in the town of Kulashwor. Her husband Shyam K. helps his wife in her work. They have two children, one son and one daughter. She opened her tailoring shop 3 years ago. Her specialty is making custom-fitted ladies' dresses like the Kurta Sulwar which are very popular among Nepali women.

Before starting her own business, Mrs. K. took a 6-month-long training course in tailoring from a tailor shop near where she lives. She seeks US$ 175 as a loan to buy raw materials like cloth, thread, and cutting material for her tailor shop. She wants to use her income for her children's education and to help support the family.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for her tailoring business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Patan Business and Professional Women - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Celeste Celestino

texts.pt:
Celeste Celestino T. lives with her husband and is mother to 5 children. She lives in the Mahotas neighborhood of Maputo. She raises and sells poultry. She also sells plastic kitchenware and various household basics from her home. She began the loan program in February 2007 with a loan of 6,000 MT [meticals, the currency of Mozambique]. She is now on her third loan cycle and is seeking 18,000 MT to pay over a 6 month period. Her business is growing. In previous loan cycles she raised 400 chicks and now intends to raise 700.

Translated by Bianca Vargas, Kiva Volunteer.

Celeste Celestino T. vive maritalmentee é mãe de 5 filhos.Vive no bairro Mahotas em Maputo. Cria e vende frangos, vende loiça plástica e diversos produtos de 1ºnecessidade na sua residência. Entrou para o programa em Fevereiro de 2007 com 6.000MT como primeiro empréstimo.Vai no 3ºciclo e vai tomar 18.000MT em 6 meses. O negócio tem estado a crescer: no ciclo anterior a cliente criava de cada vez 400 pintos e agora pretende criar 700 pintos.

loans.use: To increase stock.

loans.name: Tarimai

texts.en:
Mrs. Tarimai Maharjan has a son who studies in grade 6. She lives in a single (i.e., not extended) family. Mrs. Maharjan and her husband Ananda Maharjan make traditional idols. Idol-making work is their traditional job. 
They make idols on order. In Nepal the demand for traditional idols is increased constantly. They have not enough money to invest in their work to meet demand. So they seek a loan fo US$ 375 to buy raw materials such as silver, gold, and wax  to use to make idols.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for her work

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Patan Business and Professional Women - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Roseline

texts.en: Mrs. Roseline O. is 40 years old, and she sells fruits and foodstuff. She lives in Benin City, is married with eight children, and started her business in 1980. She has been with LAPO for the past 2 years. She is soliciting for the loan of $250 to buy more fruits and foodstuffs to sell.

loans.use: Roseline would like to buy more fruits and foodstuffs to sell.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Mrs. Helen O. a 21 years old, is married with six children, and she lives in Benin City. She sells engine oil to drivers in retail. She started her business in the year 1997. According to her if the loan amount of $350 is given to her, it will help her to buy more engine oil. She is a dedicated LAPO client.

loans.use: Helen would like to buy more engine oil to sell.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Mrs. Esther E. is dedicated to her business. She buys Soup Things from the village and sells them to people in the City. She has been with LAPO for the past 8 years now. She is married with seven children and is 52 years old. She lives in Benin City and has been in business since1987. She is requesting a loan of $675 to buy more Soup Things to sell.

loans.use: Esther would like to buy more Soup Things to sell.

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en: Mrs. Mercy O. is 30 years old and she lives in Benin City. She is married with three children and she learned this business from her mother when she started hers in 2005. She sells foodstuff and provisions to people living in her community. She will be glad if the loan of $350 is given to her. With this she can buy more foodstuff and provisions to sell.

loans.use: Mercy would like to buy more foodstuff & provisions to sell to her community.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Mrs. Esther O. is 57 years old and she started her business in 2003. She has been a member of LAPO for 3 years. She lives in Benin City and is married with five children. She is soliciting for a loan of $425 to enable her to buy more provisions and foodstuff to sell.

loans.use: Esther would like to buy more provisions & foodstuff to sell.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Mrs. Helen I. is 43 years old, she has three children and she lives in Benin City. She sells local gins to the people living in her community. She needs a $425 loan to enable her to buy more local gin to sell; she has been in this business since 1987 and in LAPO for 6 years.

loans.use: Helen would like to buy more Local Gin to sell.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mrs. Mary E. is 44 years old, she is married with four children, and she lives in Benin City. She has been in business since 2002. She sells wrappers and jewelry. She is requesting $675 to enable her to buy more wrappers and jewelry to sell.

loans.use: Mary would like to buy more wrappers & jewelry to sell.

loans.name: Roseline

texts.en: Mrs. Roseline O. produces ice cream and supplies to a retailer. She learned ice cream production for 2 weeks before she started her business in 1997. She is married with four children and lives in Benin City. She has been an LAPO client for 4 years now, and she is soliciting for a loan of $425 to enable her to buy refrigerator and ice cream materials.

loans.use: Roseline would like to buy more freezers & material needed for the production of ice cream.

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en: Mrs. Patricia E. is 43 years old, married with three children, and she lives in Benin City. She learned her business for 6 months before she went into production of ice cream in 2003. According to her if the loan amount of $825 is giving to her, it will help her to buy more materials needed for production of ice cream.

loans.use: Patricia would like to buy more ice cream supplies to make ice cream for her store.

loans.name: Euchania

texts.en: Mrs. Eucharia U. is a trained nurse who deals in the sale of drugs. She had her training for 2 years before opening her business in 1997. She is married with a child, lives in Benin City and she has been with LAPO for 5 years. She solicits for a loan of $575 to enable her to buy more drugs to sell.

loans.use: Euchania would like to buy more drugs to sell at her drugstore (she is a trained nurse).

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en: Mrs. Juliet A. sells provisions, drinks and foodstuffs. She is soliciting for a loan amount of $575 to enable her to buy more provisions, drinks and foodstuff to sell. She has been in this business since 2001 and a LAPO client for the past 4 years. She is 36 years old, she is married with five children and she lives in Benin City, Edo State.

loans.use: Juliet would like to buy more provisions, drinks & foodstuffs to sell.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Mrs. Elizabeth A. buys snails, fruits and foodstuff and sells it to people in the City. She started this business in 2001. This was a business she learned from her mother. She is 30 years old, married with two children, and lives in Benin City. According to her if the loan of $425 is given to her, it will enable her to buy snails, fruit and foodstuff to sell.

loans.use: Elizabeth would like to buy more snails, fruits & foodstuff to sell.

loans.name: Christiana

texts.en: Mrs. Christiana A. is 45 years old, she is married with four children, and she lives in Benin City. She buys yams from the village and sells them to people living in her community. This is a business she learned for 6 months before she opened her business in 2005. She is an LAPO. She is in need of $425 to buy more yams to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: Christiana would like to buy more yams to sell.

loans.name: Sandra

texts.en: Mrs. Sandra O. is 28 years old, she is married with three children, and she lives in Benin City. She started her business in 2002. She sells female clothing and she is asking for a loan amount of $575 to buy more female clothes to sell.

loans.use: Sandra would like to buy more female clothing to sell.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Mrs. Helen O. is 36 years old and is married to Mr. O. with four children. She lives in Benin City, she sells cloth and tailoring material, and also she sews female clothes. She started her business in 2005. She needs $825 to buy more tailoring material and an additional sewing machine. She is a dedicated LAPO client.

loans.use: Helen would like to buy more tailoring material & cloth for her tailoring business.

loans.name: Eugenio

texts.en:
Sixty-one year-old Eugenio C. has been married to his wife, Francisca, 53, for many years. Together they have 3 grown-up children. One of their children is already married with a family of his own, while the other two live with Eugenio and Francisca.

Eugenio has been working as a tailor for more than 20 years. It is his life’s work, and he has been dedicated to doing the best work he can. His wife, Francisca, also contributes to the family earnings through the herbal medicines that she makes and sells.

At this time, Eugenio works solely for the National Police of Paraguay. He is responsible for providing the uniforms for the police in his region. As a result of this contract, Eugenio’s business is both very constant and quite busy.

For this opportunity, Eugenio has asked for a loan that will allow him to buy more material in order to cover the many orders they receive.

loans.use: To purchase material to make uniforms

loans.name: Oghosa

texts.en: Mrs. Oghosa Eehumosele is a professional hairdresser and she started her business in 1991. She needs the loan amount of $250 to enable her to buy more relaxer, waveon and drinks to sell. She is 28 years old, married with two children, and lives in Benin City. She is a trust worthy and dedicated client of LAPO.

loans.use: Oghosa would like to buy more wave- on, relaxers, drinks etc. for her beauty salon.

loans.name: Maris

texts.en: Mrs. Maris O. is 33 years old, married with two children, and lives in Benin City. She sells medication to people living in her community. She has been in this business since 2003 and she has been a LAPO client for one year. She learned her business of selling medication from the hospital. She is requesting a loan of $625 to buy more medications to sell.

loans.use: To buy more drugs and medications.

loans.name: Anita

texts.en: Mrs. Anita L. is 25 years old, married with one child, and sells provisions and drinks in Benin. She started her business in 2006. She will be happy if this $325 loan will be given to her so she can buy more provisions and drinks for to sell. She is a dedicated client of LAPO.

loans.use: To buy more provisions and drinks.

loans.name: Mabel

texts.en: Mrs. Mabel O. is 30 years old and she has a bar where she sells drinks and pepper soup. She needs $325 to buy more drinks and soup ingredients to sell. She is married with four children and lives in Benin City. She has been in this business since 2006.

loans.use: To buy more drinks & pepper soup ingredients

loans.name: Amen

texts.en: Mrs. Amen O. is 40 years old, married with three children and lives in Benin City. She sells provisions and foodstuffs to people living in her community. She started her business in 2002. She needs $325 to enable her buy more provisions and foodstuffs for sale. She has been a dedicated client of LAPO for the past four years.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuff & provision

loans.name: Carmelo

texts.es:
Carmelo is an artesan who works with leather and suede. He creates footwear for men, with the help of one assistant. His products are sold by the dozen in the popular fairs in La Paz. He counts on this income to take care of himself and his wife. They live in the zone of Tupac Katari in the city of El Alto.

The loan will be used to purchase leather and other materials to grow his business. This is fourth loan with Impro. With his good compliance with the previous three loans, he qualifies for this other loan to help meet the demands of his market.

Carmelo es artesano en cuero y cuerina; elabora calzados para varones y tiene un ayudante. El producto es comercializado por docena en las ferias populares de la Ciudad de La Paz, constituyéndose en su fuente de ingreso con que mantiene a su esposa y a él mismo; vive en la Zona de Tupac Katari de la Ciudad de El Alto. El crédito requerido será utilizado para incrementar su capital de trabajo (compra de materia prima cuero, cartón, etc.). Es el cuarto crédito con Impro y su buen comportamiento de pago en los tres créditos anteriores le permite acceder a otro préstamo para que pueda satisfacer la demanda que tiene en su mercado.

Translated by Kiva volunteer, Emily Charnes

loans.use: TO BUY LEATHER AND OTHER MATERIALS TO GROW HIS MENS FOOTWEAR BUSINESS

loans.name: Samson

texts.en: Mr. Samson is a 30 year-old man, married with three, and lives in Benin City. He repairs cars for a living. He learned this business for four years and started his own in 1994. He needs $800 to buy more car parts and equipment. This, he said, will help him serve his customer better.

loans.use: To purchase more equipment

loans.name: Annah

texts.en: Mrs. Annah I. deals in yams and garri.  She goes to the village’s market to buy them then sells them to people in the City. She is soliciting for a loan of $400 to buy more yams and garri to sell. She has been in this business since 1986 and has been a LAPO client for three years. She is 35 years, married with six children, and lives in Benin City, Edo State of Nigeria.

loans.use: To buy more yams & garri to sell

loans.name: Gregorio

texts.es:
Gregorio is a bricklayer, working on the construction of small family homes. His wife works with him as his assistant. They also have a business raising pigs. These two activities are their major source of income to take care of their four children. They live in the zone called San Felipe de Seke in the city of El Alto.

The loan they are requesting will be used to buy pigs, whose meat they will sell at the holidays and carnivals at the end of the year. This is the fourth loan with Impro. Their previous payments records qualify them for this loan.

Gregorio es albañil (constructor de pequeñas viviendas familiares); la esposa trabaja con él como su ayudante y también se dedican a la crianza de porcinos. Estas dos actividades constituyen sus principales fuentes de ingresos con que mantienen a sus cuatro hijos; vive en la Zona de San Felipe de Seke de la Ciudad de El Alto. El crédito que ahora solicita será para capital de inversión (comprar medianos porcinos para matarlos y vender su carne en las fiesta de fin de año, y carnavales). Es el cuarto crédito con Impro, sus antecedentes de pago de los préstamos anteriores le facultan para la aprobación de su solicitud.

Translated by Kiva volunteer, Emily Charnes

loans.use: TO PURCHASE PIGS

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en: Mrs. Gloria O. is 32 years old, married with three children, and lives with her husband Mr. O. in Benin City. She has been a faithful client of LAPO for the past three years. She learned her business from her aunty and started hers in 2003. She needs a loan of $400 to buy more yams for sale. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy more yams to sell

loans.name: Miguel

texts.es:
Miguel and his wife earn their living from selling beef. They travel to the rural zones of La Paz to buy cattle, and take them to the municipal slaughterhouse so they can sell the meat wholesale in their butcher shop. This work provides them with their income to care for 4 children. They live in the zone of Villa Ingenio, in the city of El Alto.

The loan is to buy more cattle to increase their sales, and better meet the demands that exist in their market. This is the sixth loan with Impro. Miguel has been a client of Impro since 2003, and has demonstrated good compliance with the loan payments. He qualifies for this loan he is requesting as well.

Miguel y su esposa son comerciantes de carne de vacuno, viajan a las zonas rurales del departamento de La Paz para comprar ganado que luego llevan al matadero municipal y lo comercializan al por mayor y en su tienda de carnicería. Esta actividad constituye su fuente de ingreso con que mantienen a sus cuatro hijo; vive en la Zona de de Villa Ingenio de la Ciudad de El Alto. El crédito requerido es para comprar mas ganado para la venta de carne y satisfacer la cantidad de demanda que existe en su mercado. Es el sexto crédito con Impro. Miguel es cliente de IMPRO desde el año 2003 y ha demostrado un buen comportamiento de pago que le faculta para la aprobación de su solicitud.

Translated by Kiva volunteer, Emily Charnes

loans.use: TO PURCHASE CATTLE TO INCREASE THE SALES IN THEIR BUSINESS

loans.name: Philomina

texts.en: Mrs. Philomina J. is 34 years old, married with two children, lives in Benin, and she sells yam and potatoes for a living. She learned her business from her mother and started hers in 1999. She is a faithful LAPO client. She requests a $400 loan to buy more yams for sale.

loans.use: To buy more yams for sale

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Mrs. Comfort I.  said that she will be happy if you can loan her the amount of $400 because it will enable her to improve her business by buying more yams for sale. She is 58 years old and a widow with four children.  She started this business in 2002 and she learned it for three months before beginning. She has been a LAPO member for three years.

loans.use: To buy more yams for sale

loans.name: Chichi

texts.en: Mr. Chichi O. is 20 years old and learned the drink selling business for three years before he began his own business in 2005. He is requesting a loan amount of $800 to enable him meet  the demands of his customers by buying more drinks for sale. He is still single, lives in Benin City, and is also a faithful LAPO client.

loans.use: To buy more drinks for sale

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en: Mr. Emmanuel  E. a car paint dealer, and lives in Benin City with his four children and wife. He requests a   loan in the amount of $550 to buy more car paint to sell. He learned how to sell car paint for a year after which he started his own business in 2006. He is a dedicated LAPO client.

loans.use: To buy more car paint to sell

loans.name: Henry

texts.en: Mr. Henry O. a 39 year-old man who deals in the construction of iron doors and gates. He learned this business for five years and opened his in the year 1988. Mr. O. is married with two children, lives in Benin and he is a faithful LAPO client. He is in need of a $400 loan to buy materials for the production of iron doors and gates and he thanks you very much.

loans.use: To buy more materials for production

loans.name: Chima

texts.en: At 54 years old, Mr. A. Chima is married with five children, and lives in Benin City, in Edo state of Nigeria. He wants a loan amount of $400 to buy more provisions, wines, and dry gins. He learned this business for three years and started his own in 2000. And has been with LAPO for three years and is a dedicated client.

loans.use: To buy more provisions, wines, and dry gins

loans.name: Joy

texts.en: Mrs. Joy A. is a 40 year-old woman, married with four children, and lives in Benin City. She learned her kind of business for six months after which she started hers in 2002. She is a dedicated and hard-working woman.  She is requesting a $475 loan to enable her to buy more rice and soup ingredients to sell at her market. She has been with LAPO for five years.

loans.use: To buy more rice and soup ingredients

loans.name: Boniface

texts.en: Mr. Borniface M. is 46 years old, is married with two children, and deals in foodstuffs and drinks. He lives in Benin, in Edo State. He is requesting a loan amount of $550 to buy more foodstuffs, provisions & drinks to sell at his market. He has been in LAPO for a year and in business since 1996.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs, provisions & drinks

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma B. Y. belongs to the village bank “Virgen María,” which means “Virgin Mary” in Spanish.

Upon entering Norma’s small store selling “repuestos,” or auto supplies, one is instantly struck by the incredible quantity and variety of products she is able to fit into a single room. The shelves are stocked with everything from car oil and screws to sand paper and electrical wire. She has a large number of clients that rely on her store for all their mechanical needs. She is located in front of two busy auto repair shops, one of which she owns with her husband.

Norma and her husband, who is a mechanic, opened up a car workshop near their home in Ayacucho 10 years ago. It wasn’t long before they realized it would be much more profitable to open up their own parts and supplies store where they could send their customers instead of sending them to another location some kilometers away. Today Norma runs the store while her husband works across the street in his workshop. Together they serve much of the community including bus drivers, taxi drivers, and individual car owners.

One day, Norma hopes to open a second, and much larger, auto parts store to complement the one she currently owns. This is why she is so glad to be a part of her village bank. She says it has helped her learn how to save up her money so that she will eventually be able to accomplish her goals. Norma is requesting a loan of $1,000 with which she will be able to supply her store with the needed quantities of all the necessary inventory, including filters, oil, and discs.

loans.use: Norma is requesting a loan of $1,000 with which she will be able to stock her auto supply store with the needed quantities of all of the necessary inventory, including filters, oil, and discs.

loans.name: Ayao

texts.fr:
Mr. Ayao G. was born in Agoè, a suburb north of Lomé. Today he is 23 and is a single father of two (02) children. He left high school to learn motorcycle engine mechanics, but he was never able to work as a mechanic due to a lack of funds. He thus became a motorcycle taxi driver, but he does not even own the engine he uses for his job. To become self-sufficient, he has decided to buy his own motorcycle and is requesting a loan of $800 to do so. He already has significant experience as a motorcycle taxi driver and will thus be easily able to earn a decent living once he has his own equipment.

Translated from French by Kristina Jackson, Kiva Volunteer.

Né à Agoè dans la banlieu nord de Lomé, Monsieur Ayao G. est âgé aujourd’hui de 23 ans, célibataire avec de deux (02) enfants à charge. Il n’a pas eu la chance de poursuivre ses études secondaires qu’il a laissés pour se consacrer à l’apprentissage de la mécanique des engins à deux roues. Il n’eût même pas la chance, faute de moyens financiers d’exercer ce métier. Il se transforme alors en conducteurs de taxi moto, lequel engin ne lui appartient pas. Pour se prendre en charge lui-même, il décide de s’acheter sa propre moto et sollicite pour cela un financement de $800. C’est un métier qui a déjà beaucoup d’expérience dans le domaine et peut facilement s’en sortir.

loans.use: Purchase of a motorcycle taxi

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en: Samuel I. is 45 years old, is married with 7 children, and  lives in Benin City. He sells and repairs stabilizers and refrigerators. He learned his  business for 8 years and started his in 1988, also a LAPO client for 3 years. He solicits for the loan of $800 to buy equipment needed for the repair of ups, stabilizer and fridge.

loans.use: To buy more material for repair

loans.name: María

texts.en:
María B. A. is part of the village bank “Kusikuy” which is Quechua (native language) for “Happiness.” María, who is a proud mother of seven children, has been in the industry of “ganadería,” or stockbreeding, for more than 20 years. Her daily business consists of traveling great distances to the countryside where she buys young bulls and cows. These she takes to her corral outside the city where they stay for several months as she fattens them up to eventually be sold to her clients. She began when her best friend, who is also a stockbreeder, invited her to be a business partner. Together, they began with small products such as eggs and wool, and eventually branched out into the profitable business of stockbreeding.

This 27-year-old, who lights up the room with her friendly conversation and energetic character, has another business in artesanías. She and another friend meet on a regular basis to weave beautiful blankets, which she then sells to her many clients. Most of her work is on a contract basis and the majority of her clients are foreigners who wish to return to their country with a colorful souvenir. María says her goal has always been to save up enough money from both of her businesses and open a small artesanía shop around the corner from her home. As stockbreeding is a particularly strenuous way to make a living and as María grows older, opening a small store would become an especially ideal source of income.

María says she feels very happy and content to be a part of her village bank because it has taught her how to save her money and earn interest. It is also an important place for women to meet and share ideas. María is requesting a $1,000 loan with which she will be able to fund both of her businesses through the care of her cattle and upkeep of her corral, as well as materials to continue weaving artesanás.

loans.use: María is requesting a $1,000 loan with which she will be able to fund both of her businesses through the care of her cattle and upkeep of her corral, as well as materials to continue weaving artesanás.

loans.name: Angelina Deidda

texts.es:
Angelica is a diligent mother with 3 children. The 2 oldest work in the city to take care of their families. Her youngest is studying in the education center close to their home, and helps his mother with the home and the business, always making time in between his studying.

They live together with Angelica's husband. They both work day after day to improve the family's well being and take care of their youngest son. Before dedicating herself to making delicious breakfasts, Angelica worked as a seamstress in a small space she fixed up in her house. She also made pastries on request for different occasions. It was this last activity which was just a hobby, that began to generate very good income, so she decided to start selling these from the sidewalk in front of her house.

She realized that every day with her delicious recipes she was making good profit and getting more customers, so she began to increase her production and arranged the inside of her house to offer a better service to her diners. Thanks to the demand of her customers, and the benefits of improving the image of her business, she now needs to obtain a loan to buy chairs and tables, and begin renovations to convert her location into one of the most visited restaurants in her city.

Let's make it possible for this incredible woman to continue growing her business, and helping her youngest son realize his dreams.

Angélica es una diligente madre de tres hijos; los dos mayores se desempeñan satisfactoriamente en sus respectivos trabajos dentro de su ciudad a fin de otorgarles bienestar y salud a cada uno de los miembros de la familia que conformaron recientemente; mientras que el último de sus hijos aún se encuentra estudiando en un modesto centro educativo cercano a su hogar y apoya en el desarrollo de las actividades a su abnegada mamá diariamente ubicando un espacio en su atareada agenda escolar para que esta ayuda no le genere inconvenientes.

Habitan su pequeña morada en compañía de su padre y esposo que es camarógrafo de profesión y ambos (Angélica y su esposo) día a día se esfuerzan para incrementar el bienestar y calidad de vida del hijo que aún se encuentra bajo su cobijo.Angélica antes de dedicarse a la venta de deliciosos desayunos se desempeñaba como costurera en un pequeño espacio que acondicionó en la sala de su casa adicionalmente elaboraba pasteles a pedido para diversas ocasiones y acontecimientos y esta última labor que inició únicamente como un pasatiempo en poco tiempo le generó muy buenos ingresos y decidió incrementar sus ventas en la pequeña vereda fuera de su vivienda. Observó que diariamente con sus deliciosas recetas obtenía muy buenas ganancias y muchos comensales entonces fue que incrementó su producción y volvió a acondicionar el interior de su casita para ofrecer un mejor servicio a sus comensales.Gracias a la aceptación de su público y con las inmensas ganas de mejorar la imagen de su negocio se encuentra en la necesidad de obtener un préstamo para adquirir sillas, mesas e iniciar la remodelación de los ambientes con el objetivo de convertirse en uno de los restaurantes más visitados de su querida ciudad. Hagamos posible la solicitud de esta increíble mujer para que continúe cocinando con sus excelentes manos los sueños de su último hijo.

loans.use: TO BUY TABLES AND CHAIRS, AND MAKE  THE NECESSARY RENOVATIONS IN HER SMALL SHOP AND RESTAURANT, TO IMPROVE HER SALES AND THE QUALITY OF LIFE FOR HER FAMILY.

loans.name: Margarita

texts.en:
Margarita S. H. belongs to the village bank “Arco Iris,” which means “rainbow” in Spanish.

Margarita is what in Spanish is known as a "ferriante,” which means she supplies products in bulk to the community every given number of days each week. With her warm and youthful smile, she explains that three times each week she must rent a car to drive up to three hours outside city limits into the rural “campo” of Ayacucho, Peru. There she buys cheese, beef, and pork. With these supplies, she returns to the city to sell her fresh products door-to-door. Margarita began business as a “ferriante” some 22 years ago when she married her husband and started a new family.

In addition to her work supplying fresh food products to the community three times each week, Margarita also has a business in selling “leña,” or firewood, to the women in her neighborhood. Firewood is the principal means of heating homes and cooking food in this area, and everyday Margarita’s neighbors come to her to buy their daily supply.

Margarita says she is very grateful to be a part of her village bank because it has taught her how to save the profits she makes from both businesses.
